textFirst: For an ideal step-down transformer, which of the following statements is correct?

text.text3: The voltage is stepped up and the power between the coils is constant.
text.text4: The current is stepped up and the power between the coils is constant.

text.text2: The magnitude of the normal force is equal to the magnitude of the weight force.

solution: The speed of satellite is given by <equ>v=\sqrt{\frac{GM}{R}}</equ>. Therefore the larger the orbital radius, the slower the speed.

solution: The net force (centripetal force) is towards the centre of the circular path (down). The net force equals weight force - normal force. Therefore the normal force must be less than the weight.

This similar to  how different mass dropped from the same height at the same time, will reach the ground at the same time.

text.text4: The heavier cannon ball lands at a greater velocity than the lighter cannon ball.

textFirst: The light emitted from a neon vapour lamp can be best be described as
solution: The light emitted from the neon vapour lamp is a discrete number of wavelengths based on transitions between energy levels. The light emitted is spontaneous and therefore incoherent.

textFirst: Adam and Dilsha are studying the photoelectric effect and shine a monochromatic light of wavelength of [A] nm on a metal cathode. They then adjust the variable voltage supply and record the current through the ammeter. A graph of their results is shown below.

For one observation of the photoelectric effect, explain how it provides evidence for the particle nature of light.
solutions: Multiple possible correct explanations. Examples include:
• Presence of a threshold frequency indicates the energy of each photon depends on the frequency of the light and is independent of the intensity.
• The stopping voltage, and hence the kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectrons, is dependent on the frequency of the light and not the intensity of the light.
• The negligible time delay in the emitting of photoelectrons indicates the light is made up of individual photons that can be absorbed instantly.

The difference in kinetic energy is the energy lost to heat and sound

textFirst: A car (m = [A] kg) is travelling around a banked corner of radius [B] m. No sideways frictional forces are required for the car to navigate the corner at [C] km h<sup>-1</sup>.

parts.textFirst: On the diagram above, draw and label the forces acting on the car.
Determine the magnitude of the force of the road on the car.
solutions: The speed of the car in m s<sup>-1</sup>
Determine the net force on the car
Use Pythagoras' Theorem to determine Normal Reaction force.

textFirst: A toy car of mass 2.5 kg is travelling at 2.0 m s<sup>-1</sup> at the top horizontal section of the track. The ramp has length of 50 cm and provides a constant frictional force of 5.0 N to the car. The top horizontal section of the track is 10 cm above the bottom horizontal section of the track.

parts.textFirst: Find the total energy of the car when it is at the top horizontal section of the track.
solutions: The total energy is the sum of the kinetic energy and gravitational potential energy.

parts.textFirst: Find the work done on the car by the ramp.
Find the speed of the car at the bottom of the ramp.
solutions: The kinetic energy at the bottom of the ramp is the total energy at the top of the ramp minus the work down by the ramp.
Solving for the speed of the car

textFirst: Kimberly hangs a 2.0 kg mass on a spring which has a natural length of 30 cm. When she gently lowers the spring it reaches an equilibrium length of 50 cm. Kimberly then pulls the mass down so the spring stretches to a length of 60 cm and then lets go allowing the mass to oscillate.

parts.textFirst: Find the spring constant of the spring.
After the spring begins to oscillate, find the minimum length of the spring.
solutions: The spring oscillate about the equilibrium point of the spring. Therefore the minimum spring length will be 40 cm.

parts.textFirst: Find the maximum speed of the spring.
solutions: The maximum speed of the spring will occur at the equilibrium point. Therefore, find the kinetic energy at the equilibrium point.
Solve for the speed of the mass.

textFirst: An astronomer claims to have seen an Unidentified Flying Object (UFO) travelling towards the Moon at a Lorentz factor γ=[A].

parts.textFirst: Find the speed of the UFO.
The astronomer calculates that the UFO will reach the Moon in 60 seconds. From the reference frame of the UFO, how long will it take to reach the Moon?
From the reference frame of the astronomer, what is the distance between the UFO and the Moon? Is the proper or dilated distance? Explain.

textFirst: Some year 12 Physics students decide to replicate Millikan’s Oil Drop experiment. The experiment consists of two parallel electrical charged plates and electrically charged oil droplets. The students set the potential difference between the two plates to be 5.0 kV and the distance between the two plates 10 cm. One oil drop, of mass 0.3 g, seems to float, defying gravity, halfway between the two plates.

parts.textFirst: State the net force acting on the oil drop. Explain your answer.
solutions: 0 N. The weight force down is balanced by the electric force up.

parts.textFirst: The oil drop is known to be negatively charged. On the diagram above, draw 5 arrows representing the electric field lines between the two plates.
Calculate the magnitude of electric charge on the oil drop.
Find the acceleration of the oil drop if the electric field is increased to 10 kV.

textFirst: The wire is in a magnetic field produced by two magnets. The force on the current in the wire is out of the page.

parts.textFirst: On the diagram, draw the direction of the current in the wire with an arrow. Explain your answer.
solutions: The magnetic field is the right, and the force on the current carrying wire is out of the page. Using the right hand rule, the current must be down.

parts.textFirst: Explain the effect of on changing the direction of current in the wire would have on the direction of the force on the wire.
solutions: Changing the direction of the current only would reverse the direction of the force on the current carrying wire. The force would be into the page.

textFirst:
Venera 9 was the first to send images back from the surface of another planet. Venera 9 was a mission by Soviet Union and landed on the surface of Venus in 1975.

Data:

Mass of Venus: 4.90×1024 kg

Radius of Venus: 6.10×106 m

Mass of Venera 9: 1500 kg

parts.textFirst: Find the force of Venus on Venera 9 when its orbital radius is 1.22×10<sup>7</sup> m.
solutions: Read the local gravitational field from the graph, <equ>g=2.2</equ> N kg<sup>-1</sup>

parts.textFirst: Calculate the kinetic energy of Venera 9 when its orbital radius is 1.22×10<sup>7</sup> m.
Find the Gravitational Potential Energy of Venera 9 when its orbital radius is 1.22×10<sup>7</sup> m.
solutions: Find the area under the curve.

textFirst: Zuhal is experimenting with a hand crank alternator and graphing her results. A diagram of the alternator is below. When she turns the hand crank, she plots the graph of the flux vs time and the voltage vs time on separate graphs for reference.

parts.textFirst: Zuhal then changes the way she spins the hand crack and this is reflected in the flux vs time graph below. Sketch the corresponding voltage vs time graph. The scale is the same as the reference voltage vs time graph above.

Zuhal decides to replace some of the components of the alternator. When she plots the graphs of the flux vs time and the voltage vs time graphs, her results are shown below. The scales are the same as their respective reference graph. Describe the possible changes that Zuhal could have made and explain the effect that each change would have the flux and voltage graphs.
solutions: Zuhal must have changed the slip rings to a split ring commutator. This can be seen as the induced voltage is now DC instead of AC.

The magnitude of the magnetic flux and the amplitude of the output voltage have both halved. This could have been achieved by halving the area of the coil, halving the strength of the magnetic field or halving the number of turns in the coil (or some combination of reducing the area, the magnetic field and/or the number of turns).

textFirst: In the movie, The Hunger Games, the protagonist Katniss Everdeen shoots an arrow from her bow that pierces the centre of an apple. She knows that her arrows leave her bow at a speed of 80 m s-1 and an angle of 15° above the horizontal. It takes 1.5 seconds for the arrow to reach the apple.

parts.textFirst: Determine if the arrow is ascending or descending when it reaches the apple. You can use calculations to support your explanation.
solutions: Determine if the vertical component of the velocity is positive or negative after [C] s.
Since the vertical component of the velocity is positive, the arrow is on the way up.

parts.textFirst: Find the distance between Katniss and the apple.
solutions: Finally, use Pythagoras' Theorem to solve for the total distance

textFirst: A cart of mass 1.0 kg travels on a frictionless track towards a stationary 2.0 kg cart at a speed of 3.0 m s<sup>-1</sup>. After the collision of the carts, the 2.0 kg moves to the right at 2.0 m s<sup>-1</sup>.

parts.textFirst: Find the magnitude and direction of the velocity of the 1.0 kg cart after the collision.
solutions: The 1.0 kg cart will move at 1.0 m s<sup>-1</sup> to the left.

parts.textFirst: Determine if the collision is elastic or inelastic. Support your answer with appropriate calculations
solutions: Find the initial kinetic energy before the collision.
Find the kinetic energy after the collision.

textFirst: Lisa and Diane love doing Physics experiments to explore the nature of the universe. Today, they have set up a circuit with a light globe, a 12 V battery and some electrical wire as shown. The globe is rated to operate correctly at 24 W and 12 V but will turn on as long as it is using 20 W.
textSecond: Unfortunately, the globe does not light up. When Lisa measures the voltage across the globe it only reads 8.0 V.

parts.textFirst: Show that the total resistance of the connecting wires is 3.0 Ω. You can assume that resistance of the globe remains constant.
solutions: Find the resistance of the globe.
Find the voltage drop across the wires.
Since the voltage drop across the wires is half the voltage drop across the globe, the resistance of wires will be half the resistance of the globe. ∴<equ>R_{w}=3.0</equ> Ω.

parts.textFirst: Find the current in the circuit.
Calculate the power loss in the connecting wires of the circuit.

parts.beforeText: In an attempt to get the light globe to turn on, Diane decides to replace the battery with a 24 W AC supply that runs at 12 V and use two transformers as shown in the diagram. The transformers have a ratio of 1:10 and 10:1 respectively. Assume the wires connect the supply to the T1 and from T2 to the globe of negligible resistance. The connecting wires between T1 and T2 have a total resistance of 3.0 Ω.
parts.textFirst: Find the current primary coil of T1.
Find the power loss in the connecting wires between T1 and T2.
solutions: The current in the connecting wires between the transformer is <equ>\frac{2.0}{10}=0.20</equ> A.

parts.textFirst: Determine if the globe will turn on by finding the power used by the globe and calculate the voltage across it.
solutions: Find the power across the globe.
Since the power across the globe is greater than 20 W, the globe should turn on.
Calculate the voltage across the globe.

textFirst: A car of mass [A] kg is travelling around a corner banked at an angle of [B]°. The car navigates the corner of radius [C] m without any assistance from sideways frictional forces.

parts.textFirst: On the diagram above, draw the net force acting on the car.
Find the magnitude of the net force acting on the car.
Find the speed of the car as it navigates the corner.

textFirst: A hanging [A] kg mass is connected to a [B] kg mass via a light inextensible string which laid over a frictionless pulley. The [B] kg mass experiences a constant frictional force of [C] N.

parts.textFirst: Find the acceleration of the [B] kg mass.
Find the tension in the string connecting the two masses.
solutions: Isolate the [B] kg mass and solve for the tension.

textFirst: Elementary particles called muons are formed in our atmosphere, 10 km above the Earth’s surface, and travel towards the surface at 0.98c. The average life time for a muon at rest is 2.5 μs before decaying.

parts.textFirst: Using Newtonian Physics, find the distance the muon’s will travel before decaying.
Taking Einstein’s Special Relativity into account, find the distance the muon’s will travel before decaying according the measurements by the scientists on Earth’s surface.
solutions: Find the life span according to the scientists on Earth using <equ>l_{0}=γl</equ>​

parts.textFirst: Taking Einstein’s Special Relativity into account, find the lifespan of muon according to the measurements made by the scientists at Earth’s surface. Is the proper of dilated time? Explain
solutions: Find the life span according to the scientists on Earth using <equ>t=γt_{0}</equ>​
The scientists are observe the dilated time.

textFirst: A physicist working at the Australian Synchrotron is making adjustments to the electron the gun. The electron gun works by accelerating electrons in an electric field between two parallel plates. The initially settings on the electron gun have the potential difference between the two plates to be [A] kV and the distance between the plates to be [B] mm.

parts.textFirst: Find the magnitude of the electric field between the two plates. Draw four electric fields lines on the diagram above.
Find the work done on an electron starting from rest at the negative plate and exiting the gun at the positive plate.
The distance between the plates is increased. Explain:

subParts.textFirst: how the acceleration of the electrons between the plates will change.
how the speed at which the electrons exit the gun will change.
solutions: The work done on the electron will remain the same as it is equal to <equ>W=qV</equ>. Hence, the electron will exit the gun with the same speed.

textFirst: Draw six magnetic field lines around the magnet.
A satellite completes an orbit of Earth once per day.

parts.textFirst: Find the altitude of the satellite. Show your working.
solutions: Find the radius of the orbit.
Find the altitude by taking off the radius of the earth.

parts.textFirst: Calculate the speed of the satellite.

Jack says to find the gravitational potential energy of the satellite, you can use the formula E_{g}=mgh where h is the altitude of the satellite. Hari argues that when you use E_{g}=mgh you must take h as the distance from the centre of the Earth. Basmah argues that mgh is greater than the magnitude of the gravitational potential energy. Who, if any, is correct? Explain who is incorrect and why.
solutions: Basmah is correct. The gravitational field of the Earth is inversely proportional to the square of the distance. Because the satellite is much further from the centre of the Earth as the compared to the surface of the Earth, the local value of g is not constant over those distances. As g at the satellite is much less than that at the surface, using mgh to calculate the gravitational potential energy will result in a larger energy than it is in reality.

textFirst: The generator below consists of a rectangular coil with area of [A]×10<sup>-4</sup> m<sup>2</sup> and is within a uniform magnetic field of strength [B]×10<sup>-3</sup> T. The coil is spun at a rate of [C] revolutions per second.

parts.textFirst: Referring to the coils position in the diagram, find the magnitude of the magnetic flux. Explain your answer.
solutions: No magnetic field lines will thread coil OR the Area vector of the coil is perpendicular to the magnetic field.

parts.textFirst: Find the average induced voltage as the coil rotates 90° from the position shown in the diagram.
solutions: Find the time it takes to rotate a quarter turn.
Use Faraday's law to determine the average induced voltage.

parts.textFirst: Explain the position of the coil when the maximum voltage is induced.
solutions: The maximum voltage is induced when the coil is in the same position in the diagram (when the magnetic flux is 0 Wb). When the coil is rotating, the maximum rate of change of flux occurs when it reaches this position. According to Faraday's law, the induced voltage is proportional to the rate of change of flux.

textFirst: Daisy, a keen physics student, builds the electric motor below. The square coil of side lengths of [A] cm are within a magnetic field of [B] mT. The battery provides a current of [C] mA.

parts.textFirst: Find the magnitude and direction of the force on the side WX.
solutions: Using the right hand rule, the force on WX is down.

parts.textFirst: Explain the purpose of the split ring commutator.
solutions: The purpose of the split ring commutator is to change the direction of the current every half turn. This changes the direction of the forces on sides XW and YZ every half turn so that the coil can continue rotating in the same direction.

textFirst: To entertain an adoring audience, a cyclist attempts to jump from one ramp to an identical ramp shown in the diagram below. The ramps have angle of [A]° with the ground and the cyclist needs to clear a horizontal distance of [B] m to land safely.

parts.textFirst: Find the speed at which cyclist needs to leave the ramp to land safely at the other ramp?
The cyclist leaves the first ramp at [C] m s<sup>-1</sup>. How high above the top of the ramp is cyclist when they first clear it.
solutions: Find the time it takes to travel the horizontal distance between the ramps.
Find the height at that time.

textFirst: Anastasia is experimenting with a transformer that has a turn ratio of 1:[A]. She attaches a [B] W AC supply which provides an RMS current of [C] A to the primary coil.

parts.textFirst: Find the current in the secondary coil.
Anastasia’s friend Kelly argues that the as the current in the secondary has decreased, the voltage in secondary coil will have also decreased because V = IR. Explain why Kelly is incorrect.
solutions: Kelly is incorrect because the power across the primary coil will equal the power across the secondary coil. Since <equ>P=VI</equ>, so if the current has decreased, the voltage must have increased so that power remains constant.

textFirst: A ball of mass 1.5 kg, on a string is swung in a vertical circle of radius 0.5 m. When the ball is at the top of the circular path the ball is travelling at 3.0 m s<sup>-1</sup> at and the bottom of the circular path it is travelling at 8.0 m s<sup>-1</sup>.

parts.textFirst: Calculate the net force acting on the ball at the top of circular path.
Find the tension in the string when the ball is at the top of the circular path.
The string is likely to break if the tension exceeds 250 N. Explain if the string is likely to break. You may use calculations to support your answer.
solutions: The string is not likely to break as the tension never exceeds 250 N.

textFirst: In a marble run, a 100 g marble rolls from rest from a height of 50 cm, down a ramp and through a loop of radius of 25 cm. You can assume that frictional forces are negligible.

parts.textFirst: Find the speed of the marble as enters the bottom of the loop.
Determine if the ball will remain in contact with the track as it navigates the loop. Use calculations to support your answer.
solutions: No, the ball will not remain in contact with the track as it navigates the loop. The ball needs to have a minimum speed of <equ>v=\sqrt{gr}</equ> at the top of the loop to navigate it successfully. Unfortunately for the ball, at the top of the loop, the ball would only have gravitational potential energy and no kinetic energy and therefore fall off the track.

textFirst: In a toy, a marble of mass 10 g is placed in a spring-loaded cylinder. The spring is initially compressed [A] cm. Once the spring is released the marble shoots out of the cylinder at a speed of [B] m s<sup>-1</sup>.

parts.textFirst: Find the spring constant of the spring.

Mui believes that if the marble was shot out of the spring cylinder vertically upward it should leave the cylinder at 3.0 m s<sup>-1</sup> but her friend Grace believes the marble will be leave the cylinder at a slower speed than if it was shot horizontally. Who is correct? Explain your answer.
solutions: Grace is correct. The marble will leave slower because when the spring shots the ball vertically, some of the energy is converted to gravitational potential energy. When the spring shots the ball horizontal all the available elastic potential energy can be converted to kinetic energy.

textFirst: An alpha particle, of mass 6.64×10-27 kg, is accelerated to [A]c. It is travelling towards a stationary anti-alpha particle.

parts.textFirst: Find the Lorentz factor for the moving alpha particle.
Find the kinetic energy of the moving alpha particle.
The alpha particle collides with the anti-alpha particle and annihilation occurs. Both the particles are converted to energy. How much energy is produced in the annihilation of the particles.

textFirst: When Matilda goes fishing, she likes to wear her sunglasses that have polarising lenses. Explain how polarising lenses provide Matilda an advantage when she is fishing.
solutions: The reflected sunlight off the water's surface is polarised. By wearing sunglasses with polarising lenses, Matilda can block out the reflected light off the water's surface. The light that can pass through the lenses is the light has been transmitted from beneath the surface of water helping her to see where the fish are swimming.

textFirst: Students set up two speakers which play a coherent sound of [A] Hz. The students then measure the intensity of the sound at each of the set locations along the line in front of the speakers. Point D is equidistant from the speakers and take the speed of sound in air to be 340 m s-1.
textSecond: The students notice that point C is a point of minimum sound intensity and point B is a point of maximum sound intensity.

parts.textFirst: Calculate the magnitude of the distance <equ>|S_{1}B-S_{2}B|</equ>.
solutions: Point B is the first region of maximum sound intensity after the central maximum at D. Therefore the path difference is equal to the wavelength
Hence the path difference is <equ><eval>340/[A]</eval></equ> m

parts.textFirst: Explain why point C is point of minimum sound intensity.
solutions: Point C is point of minimum intensity because the path difference is equal to half the wavelength, which is <equ>PD=<eval>340/(2*[A])</eval></equ> m. This results the in the sound waves from both speakers destructively interfering which reduces the intensity of the sound.

textFirst: A bus travelling towards Mary at 20 m s<sup>-1</sup>. The bus driver sees Mary and sounds the horn which has a frequency of 350 Hz. The speed of sound in air is 340 m s<sup>-1</sup>.

parts.textFirst: Determine what Mary measures the speed of the sound waves emitted by the horn of the bus.
solutions: The speed of the sound in air isn't affected by the speed of the bus, so Mary measures the speed of the sound to be 340 m s<sup>-1</sup>.

parts.textFirst: As the bus slows to a stop in front of Mary, explain how the frequency heard by Mary changes.
solutions: As the bus begins to slow down, Mary would hear the frequency of the horn decrease.

textFirst: The optic fibre cladding consists of a transparent core and an outer cladding. The core has a refractive index of 1.50. The light is incident at the air-core boundary at 35°.

parts.textFirst: If θ is the critical angle at the core-cladding boundary, find:

subParts.textFirst: the angle θ.
the refractive index of the cladding.

parts.textFirst: If the cladding has a refractive index of 1.40, explain if the angle α should increase, decrease or remain the same for θ  to be the critical angle at the core-cladding boundary.
solutions: The critical angle for the cladding is given by
To increase the angle θ, the angle α must be reduced.

textFirst: The displacement of air particle A, in front of the speaker is shown in the diagram below.The speed of sound in air is 340 m s-1.

parts.textFirst: Find the amplitude of the sound wave.
solutions: Reading from the graph, the amplitude is 0.25 cm

parts.textFirst: Find the frequency of the sound wave.
solutions: The period of the wave is <equ>T=40×10^{-3}</equ> s

parts.textFirst: Determine the wavelength of the sound wave.

Air particle B’s mean position is 10 cm in front of air particle A’s mean position. Determine whether air particle B has a positive, zero, or negative displacement from its mean position at t = 2.0 ms. Explain your answer.
solutions: Particle B's mean position is less than a quarter wavelength in front of particle A.
At t=2.0 ms, Particle A has returned to it's mean position from a positive displacement, which occurs before it happens for particle B. Particle B must therefore have a positive displacement.

textFirst: In an experiment of the Photoelectric Effect, Kath and Kim shine an orange light of 650 nm on to a Caesium cathode that has a work function of 2.1 eV.
textSecond: Unfortunately, Kath and Kim do not measure any current on the ammeter.

parts.textFirst: Kath argues that they would get a current reading by reducing the potential difference on the variable voltage supply to 0 V and Kim argues that would be able to measure a current if they increased the intensity of the light. Explain who, if either, is correct? You may use calculations to justify your answer.
solutions: Neither Kath or Kim is correct. Each photon doesn't have enough energy to liberate an electron from the Caesium metal.
Since the photon energy 1.9 eV is less than the work function 2.1 eV no electrons will be released from the metal regardless of returning the voltage to 0 V or increasing the intensity of the light.

parts.textFirst: Kath and Kim decide to change the light source to an ultraviolet light that has a wavelength of 350 nm. Find the stopping voltage.

textFirst: Yeshani is completing an experiment on the photoelectric effect, and she plots the stopping voltage for different frequencies of light on the graph below.

parts.textFirst: Draw a line of best fit on Yeshani’s graph.
Use Yeshani’s graph to determine:

subParts.textFirst: the threshold frequency.
solutions: The line of best fit intersects the frequency axis at approximately 10.7×10<sup>14</sup> Hz, Or 1.07×10<sup>15</sup> Hz

subParts.textFirst: Plank’s constant.
solutions: Find the gradient of the line of best fit

parts.textFirst: Some common work functions for metal cathodes are Aluminium 4.1 eV, Cobalt 5.0, Caesium 2.1 eV and Magnesium 3.5 eV. Yeshani knows that her metal cathode is one of these. Determine which metal cathode Yeshani is using in her experiment. Explain your answer.
solutions: Using the graph to determine the work function. The intercept with the stopping voltage axis is closest to -4.9 eV. Hence, Yeshani's cathode is most likely Cobalt, as it has the closest work function of 5.0 eV.

textFirst: To analyse the crystal structure of a salt, Anna bombards the sample with electrons of kinetic energy 4.1×10<sup>-18</sup> J. Electrons have a mass of 9.11×10<sup>-31</sup> kg. She also finds the diffraction pattern is the same as the electron diffraction pattern when she uses X-rays.

parts.textFirst: Find the wavelength of the electrons.
Compare the following pairs of values:

subParts.textFirst: the momentum of an electron to the momentum of an X-ray Photon.
solutions: The momentum of the electron is the same as the momentum of the X-ray photon, 2.74×10^{-24}

subParts.textFirst: the kinetic energy of an electron to the energy of an X-ray Photon.
solutions: The energy of photon, 8.2×10<sup>-16</sup> J, is around 200× greater than the kinetic energy of the electron.

textFirst: The diffraction pattern for a crystal sample using electrons travelling at 2.0×10<sup>6</sup> m s<sup>-1</sup> is the same as the diffraction pattern using X-Rays.

parts.textFirst: Find the energy of an X-ray photon.
solutions: Find the momentum of the electron
Since the momentum of photon is the same as the momentum of the electron, use it to find the energy of the photon.

parts.textFirst: Explain why diffraction patterns using electrons is the same as pattern using X-rays.
solutions: The fringe spacing of the fringes depends on the wavelength. The photons and electrons have the same wavelength so they produce an identical diffraction pattern when incident on the same crystal sample.

textFirst: The year 12 Physics students are tasked with testing the sound system in the school theatre ahead of their school’s production. They find the speaker that projects the music backstage and they decide to measure the sound intensities of different frequencies at different locations in the theatre.
textSecond: In position A the high frequency and low frequency sounds are the same volume but at they are different volumes at position at position B. Explain if it is the high frequencies of the low frequencies which are louder at position B.
solutions: The low frequency will be louder at position B. The lower frequency sounds have a larger wavelength which increases the ratio \frac{λ}{w}, which leads to a larger diffraction. Because the lower frequencies will diffract more than the higher frequencies, the lower frequency sound will be louder at position B.

textFirst: Students are conducting an experiment where they shine a laser light of 6.0×10<sup>14</sup> Hz through different slits to observe the extent of diffraction for each slit. The slit widths are 3.2×10<sup>-6</sup> m, 9.7×10<sup>-7</sup> m, 7.1×10<sup>-7</sup> m, and 4.9×10<sup>-7</sup> m.
textSecond: Explain which slit width the students would expect to observe the greatest diffraction.
solutions: For significant diffraction, <equ>\frac{λ}{w}≥1</equ>, therefore the slit width of 4.9×10<sup>-7</sup> m the students would expect the greatest diffraction.

textFirst: Claire draws an energy level of a hydrogen atom.

parts.textFirst: Which energy level did Claire draw? Explain.
Explain, with reference to the following diagram, the quantised energy states of an atom.
solutions: Electrons have a wavelength. Electrons can only occupy orbits when the circumference of that orbit is a whole number multiple of the electrons wavelength. Since, there is a relationship between the wavelength and the electrons energy, only certain energy levels are possible.

textFirst: Aisha, Claire and Zehra compare two diagrams of a hydrogen atom at two different energy levels. Aisha claims that there are no energy levels between these two energy levels, Claire argues that there is a single energy level between the two energy levels and Zehra suggests that there is a continuous scale of energy and therefore an infinite number of energy levels between these two energy levels.
textSecond: Who is correct? Explain your answer.
solutions: Aisha is correct, there are no energy levels between these energy levels. The circumference of the electron's orbit must be a whole number multiple of the electron's wavelength, nλ=2πr. Since, the diagram indicates n = 3 and n = 4, there are no whole number wavelengths between these two orbits, there are no energy levels between them.

textFirst: A stream of electrons diffract as they pass through a narrow slit. With reference to the relevant physics principle, explain how reducing the uncertainty in the electrons position results in the diffraction of the electrons as they pass through the slit.
solutions: Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle says that by reducing the uncertainty in the position of the electrons, there is an increase the the uncertainty of the electrons momentum. We know that the electrons that make it to the screen have passed through the narrow slit, so we can precisely know their position. This increases the uncertainty in the electrons momentum and hence are spread out along the screen.

textFirst: Although becoming less common, sodium vapour lamps are still used as streetlights.

parts.textFirst: Describe the spectrum of light produced by the sodium vapour lamp.
solutions: The sodium vapour lamp produces a number of discrete wavelengths of light that correspond to the differences in the energy levels of the sodium atom.

parts.textFirst: Compare the spectrum produced by the sodium vapour light to the light emitted from an incandescent light.
solutions: The sodium lamp produces discrete and specific wavelengths of light whereas the incandescent light globe produces a continuous spectrum of light due to the random motion of electrons in the filament of the globe.

textFirst: Compare the light emitted from a red LED and a red LASER.
solutions: Both the LED and the LASER will produce light that is monochromatic, however the LED produces a wider ranger of wavelengths than the LASER. The LASER produces light that is coherent and collimated, where as the light from the LED is neither coherent or collimated.

textFirst: Heinrich Hertz discovered that light could liberate electrons from the surface of a metal in 1887. One observation of this experiment is that there is no time delay in the release of photoelectrons even when the intensity of the light is low. Explain how this observation provides evidence for a particular model of light. Name the experiment within your explanation.
solutions: The photoelectric effect supports the particle nature of light. When light is viewed as photons, the number of photons indicates the intensity. Reducing the intensity means reducing the number of photons. Since each photon carries energy equal to hf and the photon - electron interaction is 1-to-1, the electron will be liberated from the metal by a single electron and hence there will be no time delay in release of photoelectrons.

textFirst: Camille is conducting an experiment of the photoelectric effect. She uses a copper cathode that has a work function of 4.7 eV.

parts.textFirst: Find the maximum wavelength of light that Camille shine on the copper cathode and still measure the photocurrent.
Camille decides to use ultraviolet light that has a wavelength of 150 nm. Find:

subParts.textFirst: the stopping voltage.
the maximum speed of the photoelectrons.

parts.textFirst: Camille reduces the intensity of the UV light and notices that the photocurrent decreases. Explain if the stopping voltage increases, decreases or remains the same and how this observation provides evidence for a particular model of light.
solutions: The stopping voltage remains the same when the light intensity is reduced. Reducing the intensity of the light reduces the numbers of photons, but each photons energy remains the same, <equ>E=hf</equ>. This leads to less photoelectrons being released from the copper, but the maximum kinetic energy of the photoelectrons remains the same. The evidence of photons supports the particle nature of light.

textFirst: Priya sets up an experiment with an oscillating spring. She measures the natural length of the spring to be 80 cm. After adding a mass of 250 g to the end of the spring and gently lowing the mass, the spring extends until mass and spring reaches equilibrium. Priya then pulls the spring down an additional 10 cm before releasing the mass and allowing the spring to vertically oscillate.

parts.textFirst: Determine the equilibrium length of the spring.
Find the spring constant.
Priya wants to investigate the kinetic energy of the mass at different extension of the spring. Write a hypothesis for Priya’s experiment.
solutions: The maximum kinetic energy of the mass will occur when the spring is at the equilibrium length. This is the point where the net force on the mass is 0 N and neither accelerating or decelerating.

parts.textFirst: Over three trials, Priya measures the maximum speed of the mass to be 0.28 m s<sup>-1</sup>, 0.27 m s<sup>-1</sup> and 0.30 m s<sup>-1</sup>. Evaluate the measurements in terms of accuracy and precision. Use calculations to support your response.
solutions: Although Priya's measurements are precise they are not accurate.

textFirst: Temperance is conducting an experiment to measure the efficiency of transformers. She takes five transformers with different number of turns in the primary and secondary coils as shown in the diagram below. She applies an AC input voltage of 4.0 V to the primary coil of each transformer and measures the output voltage from the secondary coil.

parts.textFirst: Identify:

subParts.textFirst: the independent variable.
solutions: The number of turns in the primary coil.

subParts.textFirst: the dependent variable.
solutions: The output voltage from the transformer

subParts.textFirst: three control variables.
solutions: The input voltage, the turns ratio, same room temperature.

parts.textFirst: Consider the data collected by Temperance. Find the percentage efficiency of each transformer and complete the table.

parts.beforeText: In a second part of her investigation, Temperance takes the transformer T5 and changes the input voltage and measures the output voltage. Without measuring, Temperance takes the values of the input voltage directly from the variable power supply which has an uncertainty of ±0.5 V.
parts.textFirst:
Plot the graph of Output Voltage against Input Voltage.

• Axes labels and units.

• Scale on each axis.

• Uncertainty bars on the input voltage only.

• Line of best fit.
With reference to the data collect by Temperance, discuss what factors influence the efficiency of power delivered across a transformer.
solutions: According to the table, the efficiency of the transformer increases by increasing the number of turns in the primary and secondary coils. The gradient of line of best fit for the output voltage vs input voltage is 1.85. This indicates the efficiency is constant and is not effected by the input voltage over the range of 2 to 12 V.

textFirst: Tamara wants to know how the length of a pendulum affects its period. She decides to conduct an experiment where she measures the period of different length pendulums. To measure the period of the pendulum, Tamara uses a stopwatch where she believes that the uncertainty in her measurement is ±0.5 s. Her results are shown in the table below. The rule for the period of a pendulum is given by T=2π\sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}, where T is the period and l is the length.

parts.textFirst: Complete the final column in Tamara’s table.

Plot the period of pendulum against the square root of the length. Include:

• Axes labels and units.

• Scale on each axis.

• Uncertainty bars on the period only.

• Line of best fit.
Find:

subParts.textFirst: the gradient of the line of best fit.
Hence, use the gradient to determine the local of value of g.

parts.textFirst: Tamara’s friend Melanie suggests she should measure the time of 10 full oscillations and average the result to determine the period of the pendulum. Explain how making this change is an improvement Tamara’s methodology.
solutions: Making this change will decrease the uncertainty in Tamara's measurement of the period by a factor of 10, taking the uncertainty from ±0.5 s to ±0.05 s.

textFirst: An electron gun can accelerate electrons to a speed of 5.0×10<sup>6</sup> m s<sup>-1</sup>.

parts.textFirst: Calculate the wavelength of the electrons.

parts.beforeText: Christine has two slits on which to pass the electrons through. The first slit is 100 nm and the second slit is 0.1 nm.
parts.textFirst: Which of Christine’s slits is likely to produce a diffraction pattern when the electrons pass through it. Explain your answer.
solutions: Significant diffraction will occur when <equ>\frac{λ}{w}≥1</equ>. Therefore Christine should use slit 2 which has a width 0.1 nm which is comparable to the wavelength of the electrons 0.15 nm

textFirst: Some of the energy levels of lithium are shown in the diagram below. n = 1 is the ground state.

parts.textFirst: The lithium atom absorbs a photon of energy of 17 eV. On the diagram, draw an arrow to show the absorption of the photon.
Find wavelength of the photon emitted as lithium transitions from the 5th energy level to the 3rd energy level.
Find the minimum frequency of a photon that the lithium atom can absorb from the ground state.

textFirst: Explain how Young’s double slit experiment provides evidence for the nature of light. Identify the model of light in your explanation.
solutions: Young's double slit experiment provides evidence for the wave nature of light. The light from the 2 slits constructively and destructively interferes along the screen to create the alternating interference pattern. Constructive interference occurs when the path difference from the slits to the screen is a whole number multiple of the wavelength (<equ>pd=nλ</equ>) and destructive interference occurs at odd number half multiples of the wavelength (<equ>pd=(n-\frac{1}{2})λ</equ>). Interference is a wave property.

textFirst: In a double slit experiment, the laser light is directed at slits are 50 μm apart and the slits are 3.0 m from the screen where the diffraction pattern can be seen. The diffraction pattern spans 15 cm across the screen.

parts.textFirst: Find the wavelength of the laser light used to create the diffraction pattern.
Explain how the diffraction pattern provides evidence for the wave nature of light.
solutions: The diffraction is made up of alternating bright and dark fringes that arise from constructive and destructive interference respectively. The constructive interference occurs when the path difference from the slit to a point on the screen is equal to the whole number multiple of wavelength (<equ>pd=nλ</equ>) and the destructive interference occurs when the path difference is a odd number half multiple of the wavelength (<equ>pd=(n-\frac{1}{2})λ)</equ>)

textFirst: A light ray travels from one transparent material to another. The first medium has a refractive index of [A] and the second material has a refractive index of [B].

parts.textFirst: Draw the refractive ray in medium 2.
Find the angle the light ray makes with the normal in material 2.
Find the critical angle of incidence. Explain what happens to the ray if the incident angle exceeds the critical angle.
solutions: If the critical angle is exceeded, the light will be completely reflected into Medium 1.

textFirst: Two speakers are facing each other and are playing a single frequency in phase. Jennie is initially equidistant from the speakers and observes that the amplitude is maximum. The speed of sound in air is 340 m s<sup>-1</sup>.

parts.textFirst: Explain why Jennie observes maximum amplitude.
solutions: As Jennie is equidistant from the speakers, the path difference is 0 m. The sound waves will arrive in phase and constructive interference will occur resulting in a maximum amplitude.

parts.beforeText: Jennie moves 0.5 m towards the left speaker and observes the first minimum.
parts.textFirst: Find the frequency of the sound wave. Show your working.
solutions: As Jennie moved 0.5 m towards the left speaker, she is 0.5 m closer to the left speaker and 0.5 m further from the right speaker resulting in a path difference of 1.0 m. Since, this is the first minimum <equ>1.0=\frac{1}{2}λ</equ>​

textFirst: Explain single slit diffraction using the particle model of light and the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. Include the role of the narrow slit in your explanation.
solutions: Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle describes the limit to certainty we can know an particle's position and its momentum, <equ>ΔxΔp≥\frac{h}{4π}</equ>. The slit acts to reduce the uncertainty in the particle's position, an in order for the inequality to remain true, there is an increase in the uncertainty of the particles momentum, and hence direction of travel. Many photon's travelling in a wider range of directions is what is observed as diffraction as the light exits the slit.

textFirst: The Australian Synchrotron produces light by accelerating electrons around large circular vacuum tube. A laser produces light by stimulated emission.
textSecond: Compare the light produced in a synchrotron to the light produced in laser. Include a comparison of wavelengths, intensity and coherency of the light produced.
solutions: The synchrotron can produce a extremely intense light across a wide range of possible wavelengths but can be tuned to produce specific monochromatic light. It is highly coherent and polarised light. A laser, on the other hand, produces monochromatic and coherent light that is far less intense compared to synchrotron light.

textFirst: A rectangular coil has dimensions 6.0 cm × 10 cm and is moving at a speed of 2.0 cm s<sup>-1</sup> towards a magnetic field as shown in the diagram below. The strength of the magnetic field is 0.5 T.

parts.textFirst: On the axis below, draw the graph of the magnetic flux vs time of the coil from the moment the coil enters the magnetic field until the coil completely exits the field.  Include an appropriate scale on both axes.
Find the maximum EMF induced across the coil.
Over what time interval is no voltage induced across the coil? Explain your answer.
solutions: No voltage is induced between t = 5.0 s and t = 8.0 s. Faraday's Laws states that the induced EMF is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux. Between t = 5.0 s and t = 8.0 s, the flux is constant and therefore no voltage is induced.

parts.textFirst: An ammeter is connected across A and B of the coil. What direction would the current flow through the ammeter as the coil enters the magnetic field? Explain your answer.
solutions: Lenz's Law states that induced current will produce a flux that will oppose the change in magnetic flux in the coil. As the coil enters the magnetic field, the flux through the coil increases out of the page. To oppose this change, the induced current will produce a current into the page. Using the right hand grip rule, the current will flow from B to A

textFirst: A magnetic is dropped through a solenoid and exits at the bottom as shown in the diagram.
textSecond: Find the direction of the current through the ammeter as the magnet exits the solenoid. Explain your answer with reference to the appropriate law of physics.
solutions: As the magnet exits the solenoid, the flux is down and reducing. Therefore, according to Lenz's law, the induced magnetic flux will be down as to oppose the change in flux. Using the right hand grip rule, the current will flow from y to x.

textFirst: A square coil of area [A] cm<sup>2</sup> is initially in a magnetic field of strength [B] mT that is directed out of the page. An second magnetic field of strength [C] mT is adjacent to first field and is directed into the page. Over the course of [D] s, the coil is moved in a straight line from the first magnetic field to the second.

parts.textFirst: Find the average EMF induced across the coil.
Indicate on the diagram the direction of the induced current in square coil. Explain your answer.
solutions: The magnetic flux is initially out of page but reduces as it begins to enter the magnetic field out of the page. To oppose this change in flux, the induced current will produce a flux that is out of the page. The induced current will flow anticlockwise around the square coil.

textFirst: A flood light at a football ground has light globes that run off 500 V. The AC generator at the football ground is 2000 W but runs at 250 V. The total resistance in the transmission lines is 8.0 Ω. Fortunately, the club also has a step-up transformer that has 500 turns in the primary coil and 1000 turns in the secondary coil. The electrician places the transformer at the end of the transmission lines next to the flood light.

parts.textFirst: Find the current in the transmission lines.
Find the power lost due to the resistance of the transmission lines

parts.beforeText: The electrician notices that the lights are dimmer than expected and measures the voltage drop across the lights.
parts.textFirst: Find the voltage drop across the lights.
solutions: Voltage drop across the transmission lines.
Find the potential difference across the primary coil of the transformer
Find the potential difference across the secondary coil of the transformer (hence the voltage drop across the lights)

parts.beforeText: The electrician gets advice from a physicist who suggests she should move the transformer to end of the transmission lines at the generator.
parts.textFirst: Explain if the lights would be brighter if the electrician moves the transformer to the generator. Use calculations to support your answer.
solutions: The voltage in the secondary coil would be 500 V and the current would 4.0 A.
This leads to a voltage drop across the transmission lines of <equ>V_{T}=4.0×8.0=32</equ> V

Hence, the potential difference across the lights <equ>V=500-32=468</equ> V. Since the voltage drop across the lights is greater if transformer is between the generator and the transmission lines, the lights would be brighter.

textFirst: A transformer is used to reduce the voltage from the 240 V RMS mains supply to 5.0 V RMS to power a 10 W appliance.

parts.textFirst: Find the peak-to-peak voltage across the secondary coil.
Find the number of turns in the primary coil.
Find the current in the primary coil.
solutions: Find the current in the secondary coil.
Find the current in the primary coil.

parts.textFirst: Graph Kate’s acceleration over the first 10 s. Include axes labels, units and scales.
Find the change in Kate’s velocity over 10 s.
solutions: <equ>ΔV</equ> is the area under the curve

parts.textFirst: Kate’s initial speed was 5 m s<sup>-1</sup>. Find the distance Kate travels over 10 s.

Find the acceleration of mass.

textFirst: Chloe is attempting to pull a cart of mass [A] kg by pulling on a tether at an angle of [B]° to the horizontal. The tension in the tether is [C] N and the cart is point of beginning to move but remains stationary.

parts.textFirst: Find the magnitude of the frictional force keeping the cart from moving to the right.
Find the magnitude of normal force of the ground on the cart.
Find the magnitude of reaction force to the carts weight. Explain your answer.
solutions: The weight force is the force of the Earth on the cart. Using Newton's third law, the reaction force is the force of the cart on the Earth, which is equal in magnitude.
Therefore, the magnitude of the reaction force of the cart's weight is also <equ><eval>[A]*9.8</eval></equ> N

textFirst: A base jumper of total mass of 75 kg jumps from a 300 m high cliff. Assume that the base jumper begins to fall from rest and falls in vertically downwards direction. When the jumper is 150 m from the ground, she releases her parachute.

parts.textFirst: Find the gravitational potential energy of the base jumper at the top of the cliff.
Assuming that air resistance is negligible while the base jumper is in free fall, find her speed the moment before the she releases her parachute.

parts.beforeText: After the parachute is released, a constant air resistance slows the base jumper down and she lands with kinetic energy of 1000 J.

textFirst: Two students are pushing on an office chair with wheels that has a total mass of [A] kg at the same time. The first student provides a force of [B] N in the eastly direction, and the second student provides a force of [C] N in the northly direction.

subParts.textFirst: Find the magnitude of the net force acting on the chair.
Find the direction of the net force acting on the chair. Express your answer in degrees from the north correct to one decimal place.

parts.textFirst: Hence, find the magnitude and direction of the acceleration of the chair.

textFirst: A toy truck is travelling around a vertical loop of diameter [A] m.

parts.textFirst: Find the minimum speed at which the truck must be travelling at the top of the loop in order to maintain contact with the track.

Assume that the toy truck maintains a constant speed, greater than the minimum calculated in part a, around the loop. Compare how the forces on the toy truck at the top and the bottom of the vertical loop.
solutions: The net force on the toy truck is made of two forces: the weight force and the force of the track on the toy truck.
When the truck is at the bottom of the track, the force of the track on truck is up and at the top of the track, this force is down.
The weight force of the truck is always down regardless of the position of the truck on the track.

Since the magnitude of the net force is constant and is always pointing in the direction of the centre of the circular path, the magnitude of the force of the track on the truck is it's highest at the bottom and lowest at the top of the track.

textFirst: A physics student is sitting on a high wall and throws a ball at a speed of [A] m s<sup>-1</sup> and at angle of [B]° below the horizontal. The ball takes [C] seconds to reach the ground.

parts.textFirst: Find the horizontal distance from where the ball first strikes the ground to the base of the wall.
Find the height from which the ball is thrown.

textFirst: Christine is playing with a science toy known as a Netwon’s Cradle. It consists of five marbles hanging from a frame such that each marble is touching and aligned. Their undisturbed state is shown in the diagram below.
textSecond:
Christine notices that when she pulls the left most marble further left, then releases it, it collides with the resting marbles causing only the right most marble to travel to the right. Similarly, if Chistine releases two marbles on the left, two marbles on the right travel to the right after the collision.
Christine knows that in these two cases, momentum is conserved during the collision. She reasons that if she releases two balls on the left, that momentum would still be conserved after the collision if one ball on the right travelled at double the speed.
Explain why Christine never observes this case.
solutions: Christine never observes this case because despite the momentum being conserved, Energy would not conserved in this scenario. Half the mass (one ball) travels with twice the speed, would mean an doubling in the kinetic energy. Since the Newton's cradle is closed system, it has no way of spontaneously generating the extra Kinetic Energy required.

textFirst: An initially stationary tennis ball of mass 60 grams is hit with a tennis racket. The force the racket applies to applies to the ball is shown in the diagram below. Assume the ball stays at the same vertical height during the time when the ball is hit.

parts.textFirst: What is the acceleration of the ball at t = 30 ms?

subParts.textFirst: Find the impulse of the ball after the racket hits it.
solutions: Calculate Area of a triangle that has approximately the same area under the bell curve.

subParts.textFirst: Hence, find the speed of the ball after the collision with the racket.

parts.textFirst: If the strings on the tennis racket are loosened, the contact time of the ball and racket can be increased. If we assume the impulse remains the same, explain how loosened strings will affect the force the racket provides to the ball.
solutions: If impulse remains the same and the contact time between the racket and the ball is increased, the average net force acting on the ball must decrease by the same factor that the contact time has increased.

textFirst: A bungee jumper, of mass 70 kg, is connected at the ankles to an extensible rope with a natural length of 40 m and a spring constant, k = 100 N m<sup>-1</sup>. She jumps from a high bridge and is in free fall until the rope becomes taut and begins to stretch. The length from her ankles to her outstretched hands is 2.0 m.
textSecond: The bungee jumper comes to rest, just as her outstretched hands touch the water.

parts.textFirst: Find the height of the bridge able the water.
solutions: The total energy of the system must be conserved. The gravitational potential energy of the bungee jumper standing on the bridge must equal the elastic potential energy stored in the bungee rope when the jumper touches the water.

parts.textFirst: Find the bungee jumper’s maximum speed as she falls.
solutions: First find the extension when acceleration = 0 (where the magnitude of the force of gravity is the same as the magnitude of the restoring force the bungee rope)
Now, calculate the kinetic energy at that extension.

textFirst: Consider the U-shaped bar magnet. Draw 5 magnetic field lines between the poles of the magnet.
solutions: The field lines are drawn from the north pole to the south pole.

textFirst: Two electrically charged plates accelerate an electron from rest. The electron travels from the left plate to the right plate. By the time the electron reaches the right plate, it is travelling at [A]×10<sup>5</sup> m s<sup>-1</sup>.

parts.textFirst: Draw 5 magnetic field lines between the plates.
solutions: The electric field lines are uniformly spaced and are drawn from the positive plate towards the negative plate.

parts.textFirst: Is the field between the plates uniform or non-uniform. Explain your answer.
solutions: The electric field produced between two electrically charged plates is uniform. It generates an electric field that will produce a constant force on an charged particle anywhere between the plates.

parts.textFirst: Determine the magnitude of the potential difference between the two plates.

textFirst: The DC motor below has a rotating square coil with side lengths of 20 cm consisting of 50 turns which has just turned passed the vertical position. A current of 0.25 A is flowing through the coil and a force on side AB has a magnitude of 1.0 N.

parts.textFirst: On the diagram, draw an arrow on the sides AB and BC indicating the direction of the force on each of the sides of the coil.
Find the magnitude and direction of the magnetic field between the poles of the magnets.
solutions: Magnetic field is from right to left.

parts.textFirst: Explain the effect of the split ring commutator on the forces on the coil as it rotates.
solutions: The split ring commutator switches the direction of the current in the coil every half turn. This switches the direction of the forces on the sides AB and DC every half turn, when the coil is in the vertical plane.

textFirst: A solar panel generates a DC power supply which is used to run appliances inside the caravan. However, the appliances require AC voltage supply.
textSecond: Name the device used to convert the DC supply to AC and explain how it works.
solutions: An inverter is used to convert the DC from the photovoltaic cells back into AC. It works by switching the direction of the DC output back and forth to mimic the output of an AC supply.

textFirst: Consider the ideal transformer with a turns ratio of 1:25. The primary coil is connected to 10 W AC power supply and the potential difference measured across the secondary coil is 2.5 V.

parts.textFirst: Find the RMS of voltage of AC supply.
Find the current induced in the secondary coil.
With reference to an appropriate physical law, explain how the transformer steps-up the voltage.
solutions: The changing magnetic flux induced in the primary coil is transferred to the secondary coil via the soft iron core.
By Faraday's Law, <equ>EMF=-N\frac{ΔΦ}{Δt}</equ>, a voltage is indcued across the secondary coil.
Because the secondary coil has more turns than the primary coil, a greater voltage is induced across the secondary coil.
